Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Parsing the effects of host specificity and geography on plant-fungal symbioses under climate change
Award.AbstractNarration:
Climate models project higher temperatures, more variability in precipitation, and more extreme weather events in the future. Under such changing environments, foundation plant species, which promote stable conditions for other species and support fundamental ecosystem processes, may benefit from microbial partners that enhance plant survival during climate extremes. However, whether microbial partners can help buffer ecosystems against climate change remains unknown. This research investigates a widespread, but poorly known, group of fungi that commonly grow in the roots of dominant forage grasses. The project determines how the benefits of these fungi vary along gradients of drought and heat stress, differ among grass species, and shift across geographic regions. This work has high promise for identifying fungi that help plants survive and grow in stressful climates. Together, this team will integrate research activities into a new high school teacher training program that focuses on underserved communities and a set of laboratory modules for middle school workshops. Results will shed new light on the functions of microbial partners in maintaining grassland and rangeland productivity, improving the ability to conserve, manage, and restore these important areas in future climates.

Deeper insight into the biology of root endophytes has the potential to transform understanding of how plants respond to drought and heat in the same way that studies on mycorrhizal fungi overturned paradigms about how plants acquire nutrients. This project tests whether root-associated fungi benefit dominant grassland plant species, which may moderate the loss of net primary production during droughts and heat waves. The work addresses the following questions: (1) What is the relative importance of host species identity versus geographic and climatic gradients in explaining variation in symbiont abundance and composition? (2) How strongly do host species identity and geographic origin influence the magnitude of symbiont benefits across gradients of heat and drought stress? (3) Can symbiont-mediated amelioration of stress be generalized from laboratory settings to predict outcomes in the field? Activities include field surveys along latitudinal gradients, next-generation high-throughput sequencing of root fungi, development of a large fungal culture collection, multi-factor greenhouse trials that manipulate drought and heat, and field tests that leverage existing, large, cross-site rainfall experiments. Novel aspects of this project include characterizing root-associated fungal composition along latitudinal gradients, testing the hypothesis that symbioses become more beneficial to plants under increased abiotic stress, and determining how endophytic root fungi affect plant hosts under field conditions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We completed a research collaboration that aimed to better understand how root-associate fungi and their communities change across North American grasslands ranging from southern Texas and New Mexico to Nebraska, Kansas and Wyoming. We established a collection of pure cultures that has served as a resource to support genome sequencing of several individuals in collaborations with Los Alamos National Laboratory and Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, latter of which just completed a draft genome of a potential new species (Fusarium). Results from our broad continental sampling show that plant hosts structure the fungal communities and that environmental factors are secondary. Importantly, fungal diversity does not follow typical latitudinal declines, although the fungal communities become more similar and homogeneous at the edge of the host plants’ range. These results suggest that fungal communities are most sensitive to indirect effects of host responses and edaphic factors than to changing climate as predicted under global change. We also used experimental manipulations of rainfall to assess effects of drought on these fungal communities. These experiments provided contrasting results. In one experiment, drought manipulation altered fungal communities, although environmental background was a better predictor of the observed responses than the drought treatment itself; in another, communities did not respond to drought, but similar environmental background effect was obvious. In sum, we conclude that changes in grassland communities likely depend both on the indirect effects of climate on host plants and to a lesser degree to the direct climate effects. We commonly engage undergraduate trainees in research. In one such undergraduate project that is currently being considered for publication in a peer-reviewed journal, we aimed to estimate the proportion of fungi in environmental samples that can be cultured on manmade media. This is an important issue because we estimate that only 1% of bacteria are culturable, but comparable estimates for fungi have been missing. Based on our experiments, we estimated that more than 10% of all fungi and up to an excess of 20% some broad fungal groups (phyla) can be cultured. These results have appeared in 16 conference presentations, five (5) accepted publications and in two (2) currently under revision, one of which is authored by an undergraduate student.

We also engaged eight (8) undergraduate and graduate three (3) students in research and generated fungal resources that benefit broader research communities. In training, the pandemic compromised some of our training capabilities because virus transmission precautions limited in-person training. Despite this, at Kansas State University, we engaged undergraduates (4 female, 1 Latina, 4 male) and three graduate students (2 female, 1 male) in research directly related to this program or using resources generated in the course of this program. We also provided an opportunity for a larger undergraduate student population through participation in a program coordinated by our Office of Undergraduate Research and Creative Inquiry (OURCI). The OURCI program aimed to provide access to a limited research project, results of which the students the presented in an undergraduate symposium. In addition, the research on estimating the proportion of culturable fungi (above) stimulated development of a Course-based Undergraduate Research Experience (CURE) component for Kansas State University’s General Microbiology and Biology of Fungi classes with enrollment of more than 300 and 15 students per year, respectively. This CURE curriculum was scheduled for a pilot run in summer 2020 but was delayed because of the pandemic. Plans to make the CURE available in future semesters are in place and the instructors for both classes have agreed to continue collaborating. We have used the culture collection now housed in Western Illinois University (WIU) to generate further resources. A graduate student has built a Master or Science program comparing isolates from dry and wet grasslands to ask the simple question whether fungi that originate from different environments also differ in their environmental tolerances. These fungi are now being genome-sequenced and their proteomes analyzed when either environmentally stressed or non-stressed to improve our understanding how fungi may cope with environmentally adverse drought conditions. The genome and proteome data will be available for broader comparisons by other researchers
